results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 05-07
results.brief_description: Continuing the television series presented by Simon Schama on the history of Britain. This video contains the following episodes: “King death” (1348 to 1500) - Is the story of the Black Death, a disease which killed almost 45% of the English population. Also covers the Peasants Revolt, Richard II’s attempts to quell the revolt, Henry Bolingbroke and the Wars of the Roses. “Burning convictions” (circa 1500 to 1558) - Sees Henry VIII assert himself as Head of the Church of England triggering the English Reformation and the demise of the Catholics. Edward VI and Elizabeth I lead the way for Protestantism and patriotism. “The Body of the Queen” (1558-1603) - Is about two queens, Elizabeth and Mary, Queen of Scots and the rivalry for religious power between them. Intrigue, plots, the Spanish Armada and at the heart of it all, Elizabeth’s dream of a “great Britain” see Elizabeth surviving and Mary executed. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.

results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 01-04
results.brief_description: Writer and presenter of this epic television series of fifteen episodes, Simon Schama - University Professor at Columbia University in New York, internationally acclaimed for his best-selling books including “Citizens” (1989), “Landscape and memory” (1995) and “Rembrandt’s eyes” (1999) - manages to make what could be a dull and laborious story into a fascinating, informative and historical biography, enriching and expanding our knowledge of the history of Britain from circa 3100 BC through to the present day. Schama uses the art of story-telling, actual locations of historic importance, paintings, stills, artefacts and architecture, superb photography, vivid re-enactments and some of Britain’s ancient and atmospheric landscapes in the production of this brilliant series. This video contains the following episodes: “Beginnings” (circa 3100 BC to 1000 AD) - Covers the 4000 years that precede the Battle of Hastings, including the Roman invasion, the building of Hadrian’s Wall, King Alfred and Anglo-Saxon England. “Conquest” (circa 1000 to 1087) sees the end of Anglo-Saxon England by the Normans, the rise of Anglo-Norman England and King William’s commissioning of the Domesday Book in 1066. “Dynasty” (circa 1087 to 1216) - Tells about the Angevin dynasty with Henry II bringing in a system of laws and civil service after the chaos and carnage of the Conquest. Also features two of Henry’s sons, Richard the Lionheart and John, whose failure encouraged his Barons to publish the Magna Carta. “Nations” (circa 1216 to 1348) - Finds England at the centre of the Welsh, Scots and Irish nations search for identity and independence. Also follows the rise of Edward I as he leads England to war against these nations and begins to develop his own system of empire building. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.

results.title: A History of Australian art. Part 3 (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian art”.
This is a definitive collection of important Australian artists from the period 1970-1991. It investigates experimental art - Performance and Happenings, the influence of Feminism and the international and commercial success of Aboriginal art. Key works from galleries across Australia and a lively commentary provide an informed history emphasising critical developments in Australian art. Includes high-resolution images, multi-level presentations and commentary, full lists of artists with additional information, close-up views of any part of each image and a detailed study guide with key to the works. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Macintosh LC, 2MB RAM, 1MB free disc space, 8 bit colour card, system 6.0.5 or higher, CD ROM XA. IBM PC and Compatible; Windows 3.1 or higher, 4MB RAM, 4MB free disk space, VGA display, MPC Compatible CD ROM XA.

results.title: A History of Australian art. Part 2 (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian art”.
This is a definitive collection of important Australian artists from the period 1920-1970. From Margaraet Preston to Brett Whitely, controversial modernist art, and the influence of American styles such as Abstract Expressionism. Key works from galleries across Australia and a lively commentary provide an informed history emphasising critical developments in Australian art. Includes high-resolution images, multi-level presentations and commentary, full lists of artists with additional information, close-up views of any part of each image and a detailed study guide with key to the works. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Macintosh LC, 2MB RAM, 1MB free disc space, 8 bit colour card, system 6.0.5 or higher, CD ROM XA. IBM PC and Compatible; Windows 3.1 or higher, 4MB RAM, 4MB free disk space, VGA display, MPC Compatible CD ROM XA.

results.title: A History for the future: Australian women in science and technology
results.brief_description: This video brings out of the shadows some Australian women whose achievements in science and technology have been largely unacknowledged. It attempts to redress the situation by bringing into focus some examples of their successes. It also makes the point that through the determination and dedication of women in the past, women today have inherited the right to forge a career for themselves in any field they choose. Evocative vignettes from the past together with pictures and interviews featuring modern women form an excellent vehicle for further discussion. Suitable for years 7 - 12.

results.title: A Hill in Korea = Hell in Korea
results.creator_credit: Wessex Film Productions, British Lion Films, Anthony Squire and Julian Amyes
results.brief_description: Based on true events and the novel by Max Catto, “A Hill in Korea” is a portrayal of a small group of British soldiers in action during the Korean War. Their combined enemy is communism and the Chinese soldiers who have landed in North Korea to support the North Korean Army. Whilst performing a routine sweep of a small communist-held village, the British patrol unwittingly find themselves trapped and surrounded by an army of Chinese soldiers. It becomes a life and death battle as they attempt to escape, but inevitably they are forced to the top of a small hill where the last stand is made in a deserted Buddhist Temple. Starring George Baker, Stanley Baker, Harry Andrews and featuring - briefly - a very young Michael Caine making his film debut and Robert Shaw in a supporting role in only his second film. Cast also includes Michael Medwin, Ronald Lewis, Stephen Boyd, Victor Maddern, Harry Landis.

results.title: A Heritage to build on
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, Humphrey Swingler and Derek Williams
results.brief_description: Made as part of the Cement and Concrete Association’s contribution to European Architectural Heritage Year 1975, shows the many types of Britain’s old and modern architecture. It contrasts the present time, when renewal and renovation of urban environment is a matter of concern, with the past. It shows that with thoughtful use of today’s materials such as concrete, old and modern buildings can be compatible with those of the past.

results.title: A Heart in winter = Un Coeur en hiver
results.creator_credit: Film Par Film, Cinea, Orly Films, SEDIF, D.A. Films, Paravision International, FR3, Jean-Louis Livi, Philippe Carcassonne and Claude Sautet
results.brief_description: Daniel Auteil and Emmanuelle Beart (the leading actors from Manon Des Sources) star in this triangular love story which explores the darker recesses of the heart and soul; where emotion is repressed. Two longtime friends in the classical music world find their friendship is threatened when a beautiful woman enters their lives. Ravel’s music forms a striking background to the drama as one woman embarks on a journey of surrender to passion.

results.title: A Hard day's night
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Walter Shenson and Richard Lester
results.brief_description: Starring the Beatles, this comic fantasia with music uses a multitude of cinematic gags. An enormous commercial success, it led directly to all the kaleidescope swinging London spy thrillers and comedies of the late sixties. In this film the Beatles, harrased by their manager and Paul’s grandpa, embark from Liverpool by train for a London television show.

results.title: A Hard course
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Stanley Williamson and Arthur Smith
results.brief_description: The arguments for and against the system of intensive training for boys and girls at the Outward Bound Mountain School in Cumberland. The school aims at “character training through adventure and testing experience”.
